channel.title: [Delphi] Buttons
channel.description:
On normal web browsers when you type the web site in, and hit enter it takes you to where you want to go. In my crappy home made one, you have to actualy click the button. How would on make it so when you hit enter it does what the button does?
oh and yes, i am VERY bad at explaining things.

item.title: [Delphi] Buttons
item.dc:creator: @1_dum_taco 1 dum taco
item.description:
@1_dum_taco wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:11, topic:157475”]procedure TForm1.Button1Click(Sender: TObject); var url : string; begin url := edit1.text; webbrowser1.navigate(url); end; [/quote] Thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: [Delphi] Buttons
item.dc:creator: @1_dum_taco 1 dum taco
item.description:

[quote=“lawl, post:3, topic:157482”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=214710.msg1875407#msg1875407 date=1194521698]
But we are talking about buttons, not text fields.
[/quote]
hes talking about a text field for the address bar[/quote]No, the ‘Go’ button that takes you to whatever’s in the address bar.

Read full topic

1 dum taco:

How would on make it so when you hit enter it does what the button does?

item.title: [Delphi] Buttons
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“1 dum taco, post:5, topic:157475”][quote author=The Un-Named link=topic=214710.msg1873690#msg1873690 date=1194467641]
Click your form, on your Object Inspector, set KeyPreview to true. Then go to Events, double click OnKeyPress drop down box, it should take you to the Code Editor, do something like the following:

if Key = #13 then
Button1.Click;

and it should work.

(Key 13 is enter, 10 is newline).

I’ve uploaded my .pas and .dfm files if your still having trouble.
[/quote]Thanks. Works perfectly =)

Is there a way to take something like webbrowser1.navigate(edit1.text) so that when a button is clicked it takes you to a website (home page/ whatever)?[/quote]

I’ve never worked with web browsers in Delphi, however I’m sure you’ll find an answer with source code on google.

Read full topic

if Key = #13 then

and it should work.

I’ve uploaded my .pas and .dfm files if your still having trouble.[/quote]Thanks. Works perfectly =)

item.title: [Delphi] Buttons
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Click your form, on your Object Inspector, set KeyPreview to true. Then go to Events, double click OnKeyPress drop down box, it should take you to the Code Editor, do something like the following:

if Key = #13 then
Button1.Click;

and it should work.

(Key 13 is enter, 10 is newline).

I’ve uploaded my .pas and .dfm files if your still having trouble.

Read full topic

item.title: [Delphi] Buttons
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:1, topic:157482”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=214710.msg1873168#msg1873168 date=1194425187]
In java you would set a Mnemonic on that button for the Enter key. It will be similar for Delphi, look at the API for whatever button class you used, or something like that.
[/quote]
no, in java you would add a action listener to the input field, but why are we talking about java l0l[/quote]

You could do that, or you could do it the easy (correct) way:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/javax/swing/AbstractButton.html#setMnemonic(int)

And the reason I mentioned java in this thread is because he would need to look for something similar in Delphi, most languages have many similar features.

Read full topic
